channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: India Ink: An Icon of Indian Roads Is Set Out to Pasture
item.description: In the final stage of a long decline, Hindustan Motors announced in May that it would suspend production of the Ambassador, a car that was once synonymous with style and status.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Kenya’s Bright Financial Future Clashes With a Grim Present
item.description: Investors worldwide have flocked to Kenya’s debut Eurobond, even as terrorism damages the country’s tourism and hundreds of thousands remain jobless.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:credit: Sven Torfinn for The New York Times
item.media:description: A poster of President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya in the outskirts of Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: People’s Daily Takes Firm Stance Against Urine Consumption
item.description: The Communist Party newspaper said the practice, which has received a recent burst of publicity, has no medical value.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: The 100-Year Legacy of World War I
item.description: Articles, maps and archival materials tell the story of the war’s lasting impact.

item.title: Sudan: Christian Woman Freed Again
item.description: A Sudanese Christian woman whose death sentence for abandoning Islam was overturned was freed again after being detained on accusations of forging travel documents.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Honduras Releases Jailed Florida Crew
item.description: Six Americans who traveled to the Mosquito Coast of Honduras last month planning to dredge a river but ended up in jail have been released.

item.title: In the Shadows of Shrines, Shiite Forces Are Preparing to Fight ISIS
item.description: Security officials in Iraq’s Shiite holy twin cities, Karbala and Najaf, scoff at the extremist Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, saying their defense forces are ready to meet the threat.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: As Pakistan Advances Against Taliban, Fleeing Civilians Pour Into Northern Towns
item.description: Officials said that more than 500,000 refugees had arrived in Bannu, Waziristan, by Thursday morning.
item.dc:creator: By IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD and ISMAIL KHAN
item.media:description: Pakistanis displaced by a government offensive waited for packages of food and cash in Bannu.

item.title: Jean-Claude Juncker, Quietly in Eye of E.U. Storm
item.description: Jean-Claude Juncker, a former prime minister of Luxembourg, has become the European Union’s most divisive figure in his run for president of its executive branch, while revealing little of himself.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:credit: Titus Simoens for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jean-Claude Juncker of Luxembourg, on his campaign bus in Belgium while running for president of the European Commission.

item.title: Redrawn Lines Seen as No Cure in Iraq Conflict
item.description: Fragmentation appears inevitable, but the tensions that divide may fuel new conflicts over ideology and natural resources.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Clerics in support of the Mahdi Army marched last week in a show of force against ISIS in Najaf, Iraq. Shiites are taking up arms across the country and calling on civilians to join the fight.

item.title: Yemen: Militants Attack Airport
item.description: Militants attacked an international airport, a military barracks and a post office in the southern city of Sayoun on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Panmunjom Journal: High Tension and a Cold Shoulder at Border of Two Koreas
item.description: On the front line of what is technically the continuing war between North and South Korea, daily life is an odd mix of high tension and mundane routine.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: A North Korean soldier, right, faced a South Korean soldier at the border village of Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone.

item.title: Guantánamo Detainees’ Lawyers Urge Obama to Approve Release to Uruguay
item.description: Also this week, a military judge overseeing a war-crimes tribunal issued an order that generated new dispute over how much classified information the C.I.A. must give defense lawyers.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Pressure Loss Is Explored in Vanishing of Jetliner
item.description: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 appears to have been on autopilot as it flew south, and the crew may have been unresponsive, according to a new Australian report.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Where Killings Are Common, Death of Activist Stuns Benghazi
item.description: The killing of Salwa Bugaighis silenced a lawyer who helped propel the 2011 uprising and who tried to broaden Libya’s notions of rights and citizenship.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: The death of Salwa Bugaighis has stunned a nation where assassinations, kidnappings and explosions have intruded on life with a dulling regularity.

item.title: Obama Requests Money to Train ‘Appropriately Vetted’ Syrian Rebels
item.description: President Obama requested money from Congress to train and equip what the White House is calling “appropriately vetted” members of the opposition, reflecting increased worry about the spillover of the Syrian conflict into Iraq.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: U.S. Phasing Out Its Counterterrorism Unit in Philippines
item.description: American Special Forces will continue to help Philippine security forces counter a smaller, lingering Islamist threat, but the size of the mission will drop to a dozen or so advisers from its current 320 service members.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: The Great War: World War I Brought Fundamental Changes to the World
item.description: It destroyed kings, kaisers, czars and sultans; it demolished empires; it introduced chemical weapons; it brought millions of women into the work force.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Israel Names Prime Suspects in Abductions
item.description: Describing Marwan Qawasmeh and Amer Abu Aisha as “Hamas activists,” Israel said it had been hunting for the two since the kidnapping of three teenagers came to light.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Germany 1, United States 0: World Cup 2014: Germany Defeats U.S., but Americans Advance
item.description: Germany beat the United States on Thursday to win Group G, but the Americans advanced to the knockout stages after Portugal beat Ghana, 2-1.
item.category: United States Men's National Soccer Team
item.dc:creator: By SAM BORDEN
item.media:description: Clint Dempsey was sandwiched between Germany’s Per Mertesacker, left, and Jérôme Boateng during Thursday’s match.

item.title: News: Slain Libyan Rights Activist Documented Her Last Hours Online
item.description: One of Libya’s most prominent civil rights activists, Salwa Bugaighis, was assassinated in her home in Benghazi on Wednesday, shortly after she posted an image of militiamen outside her home on Facebook.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: DealBook: Teabox Seeks to Bring India’s Teas Into Modern Era
item.description: With the backing of venture capital, an entrepreneur is seeking to bring high-quality Indian teas rapidly to global consumers via his retail website, Teabox.
item.dc:creator: By SARITHA RAI
item.media:description: Tasting at the Goomtee tea estate, a supplier to Teabox.

item.title: U.N. Official Says Syrian Rules Are Preventing Aid Delivery
item.description: New bureaucracy by the Syrian government has kept food and medicine from reaching civilians trapped by war, the Security Council is told.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Violence and Uncertainty Mar Libyan Election for a New Parliament
item.description: Voters cited growing disillusionment with Libya’s post-revolt leaders in explaining why so many chose not to cast ballots Wednesday for members of a new Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and SULIMAN ALI ZWAY
item.media:description: Women voted Wednesday at a polling station inside a Tripoli school as Libyans elected members of a new Parliament.

item.title: Support for Maliki Slips Within His Own Party as Armed U.S. Drones Start Flights
item.description: Alarmed at the Sunni insurgency, even some supporters of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki say they doubt he should serve a third term.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND, ERIC SCHMITT and SUADAD AL-SALHY
